awd_titl_txt: Gauging and Optimizing Solid-State Nanopore Sensing Performance for Polysaccharide Sensing and Glycomics
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program and the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program (Division of Chemistry), and the Nanobiosensing Program (Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems), Professor Jason Dwyer and his group at the University of Rhode Island are developing new nanofabricated sensors to enable better characterization of an important class of biomolecules known as polysaccharides, or glycans. Glycans play important roles as a source of energy, as markers in important biological processes, and can also serve therapeutic functions - for example, the anticoagulant heparin is the most prominent medically useful polysaccharide. Identification and characterization of glycans can be incredibly challenging, in part because they are made from more than 100 different sugar building blocks connected in a variety of different ways. Drug safety can require detection of subtle and often low-abundance variants; in 2008, failure to detect a toxic contaminant in heparin resulted in ~100 deaths in the U.S. The Dwyer group is developing a rapid and inexpensive tool for selective analysis/screening of glycan samples. Students involved in this multidisciplinary work learn about nanofabrication of chemical measurement devices that have the potential to be used easily where they are needed, not just in a specialized chemistry laboratory staffed by highly trained scientists.  Thus, broader impacts derive not only from potential nanopore-based assays for targets like heparin, but also from student classroom and laboratory exposure to the principles and practice of microfluidics, 3D printing, and computer-aided design, as well as the nature of innovation and technology transfer.

The approach taken by the Dwyer group utilizes nanopores for single molecule sensors and manipulators.  Specifically, representative polysaccharides are being targeted using thin-film silicon nitride nanopores of varying sizes and surface chemistries (e.g. charge-polarity).  Covalent and noncovalent labelling of the glycans is used to tune sensitivity and selectivity.  Interactions among polysaccharides are also being studied.  More broadly, the work addresses the design and reproducibility of chemically functionalized nanopores for glycomics, genomics, and proteomics, ideally with the potential for low barriers to widespread adoption.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Glycans form an important class of biomolecule: storing and providing energy (sugars), holding clinical therapeutic utility (e.g. the anticoagulant heparin), and serving as a biological marker and information carrier (most familiarly as the molecular signifier of blood type). Just as with the more familiar DNA and protein biomolecule classes, glycans consist of strings of molecular subunits (monomers) linked together. Glycan identity and function depend on the number of such monomers linked together (molecular size), and the types and ordering of the different monomers present (sequence). Accurately determining the size and sequence of glycans, however, remains a forbidding task?principally for (1) a lack of tools, and (2) the staggering number of glycan monomers?120, versus 20 for proteins and 4 for DNA.

We have worked to explore, apply, and develop a tool called a nanopore to the chemical analysis of glycans. This nanofluidic device is sensitive to single molecules, capable of generating a signal in response to each suitable biomolecule that passes within its sensing zone. It is already in clinical use for DNA sequencing, but glycans are a far more challenging sequencing target than DNA. Glycans are also more challenging to sequence than proteins, and the first successful nanopore protein sequencing efforts were reported only in 2021. The feasibility of using nanopore to chemically analyze glycans was therefore unclear, and it was even more uncertain whether nanopores might provide glycan sequence information.

The intellectual merit of our grant-funded work is manifold. (1) We have expanded the range of glycans that have been successfully detected and fingerprinted using nanopores. This gives us a library of information for further study and use. It also provides impetus and justification for further application and development work?that is, it demonstrates feasibility. (2) We have learned how nanopore sensing of glycans requires a forefront consideration of a phenomenon (electroosmosis) often disregarded in nanopore DNA sensing. This therefore expanded our understanding, at a fundamental level, of how this single-molecule tool functions. The practical consequence of this different phenomenon is that we can successfully detect charge-neutral glycans that were otherwise widely considered out of reach. (3) We invented a new way to chemically decorate nanopores, allowing us to use different molecules on the nanopore surface to optimize its performance. This is allowing us better insight, down to the molecular level, into how nanopores work and is also expanding their utility, reliability, and breadth of application. (4) We have demonstrated, on different examples of glycans, the utility of machine learning in differentiating between those glycans by their nanopore fingerprint. (5) In 2021 and in 2022 we were able to use machine learning analysis to detect sequence differences between glycans at the monomer level?a powerful indication that nanopore glycan sequencing could be feasible.

The broader impacts of our work can be largely summarized by reference to the 2012 National Research Council Consensus Report Transforming Glycoscience: A Roadmap for the Future. It pointed out that glycans are omnipresent in biological processes and major diseases and are a source of energy and potential therapeutic function. Given the difficulty of glycan analysis using conventional chemical analysis methods, it consequently called for transformative tools to detect and characterize glycans and argued that it should be a high priority for funding agencies such as the FDA, NIH, and NSF. (1) We have widened the utility of nanopores beyond genomics and proteomics to glycomics. (2) We have improved our ability to control nanopore fabrication and performance which will be beneficial for its use in the characterization of glycans as well as of other (bio)molecules. (3) We have studied molecules with direct and current clinical/therapeutic uses. More broadly, our development of nanopore fingerprinting as a tool for quality assurance will be useful in ensuring the purity of pharmaceuticals at the level of screening of single molecules. (4) Our work in materials science and sensing has potential applications in biopolymer information storage schemes. Going beyond the study of glycans, specifically, the nanofluidic aspect of nanopore sensing is not a part of the typical undergraduate chemistry curriculum, and it has utility well beyond nanopore sensing. We have implemented and developed enquiry-based undergraduate laboratory experiments to familiarize the next generation of scientists with the exciting, powerful, and enabling nanofluidic domain of science and technology.

 


Last Modified: 08/31/2022
Modified by: Jason R Dwyer
